docs.lead_paragraph: Factory employment resumed its decline in September, but the economy generated enough service jobs to swell overall payrolls by 121,000, Labor Department figures showed today. The unemployment rate, meanwhile, remained at 5.6 percent, about where it has hovered for a year.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boeing Company's largest group of union workers went on strike yesterday after voting down a new three-year contract offer, with 78 percent opposed and only 22 percent in favor.

headline.main: Union Rejects Boeing Offer; Goes on Strike In Three States

docs.lead_paragraph: Budget bills drafted by both houses of Congress would repeal tough Federal standards for the quality of care in nursing homes, even though the industry says it has not sought wholesale elimination of the standards. Since those standards were adopted in 1987, nursing homes have reduced the use of tranquilizers, sedatives and other drugs, and the use of physical restraints has dropped sharply. Linda Keegan, vice president of the American Health Care Association, a trade group for nursing homes, said today that fewer than 20 percent of nursing home residents were physically restrained, compared with more than 40 percent in the mid-1980's.

headline.main: BILLS WOULD RELAX FEDERAL CONTROLS ON NURSING HOMES

docs.lead_paragraph: After two weeks of intensive and sometimes bitter negotiations, during which the musicians of the New York Philharmonic let one strike deadline pass and postponed a second, the players voted yesterday to accept the latest contract offer from the Philharmonic-Symphony Society. The vote, which was counted moments before a 7 P.M. strike deadline that could have brought on the orchestra's first walkout since 1973, was 76 to 21, said Judy West, the spokeswoman for Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians. The musicians performed their scheduled 8 P.M. concert at Avery Fisher Hall. Although the contract passed the ratification vote, the musicians and their representatives say they are by no means happy with it or with the way it was negotiated. I. Philip Sipser, their lawyer, said that he had never seen players angrier than those of the Philharmonic and that he expected the bitterness to linger.

headline.main: Philharmonic Strike Averted as Musicians Agree to a Contract

docs.lead_paragraph: Production workers at the Boeing Company overwhelmingly rejected the company's final contract offer late today and voted to go on strike. No talks were planned and picketing was set to begin early Friday morning. Union leaders had called the company's offer insulting.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican proposals on Medicare came under fire today from the American Association of Retired Persons, the American College of Physicians and a coalition of businesses that provide health insurance benefits to workers and retirees. Speaker Newt Gingrich courted the elderly all summer, hoping to win their support for the Republicans' Medicare plan. But Tess Canja, a member of the board of the association, said today that the Republicans were cutting "too much, too fast" by proposing to slice $270 billion, or 14 percent, from projected spending on Medicare over the next seven years.

headline.main: Retirees' Group Attacks G.O.P. Health Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: Group life and health insurers would be able to use blood tests to screen for H.I.V. and deny coverage to applicants who test positive, under a proposal by the Department of Insurance. The department said that insurance companies already circumvent a ban on testing blood to screen for the AIDS virus by using urine testing and other procedures. Under the new proposals, if insurers require screening for AIDS, it must be through medically accepted practices like blood tests. The department issued a statement yesterday saying that since insurers already routinely screen out candidates for heart disease, cancer and other conditions, "there is no basis to discriminate between these conditions and H.I.V. infections."

docs.lead_paragraph: After months of public silence, the American Medical Association expressed deep concern today about Republican proposals to redesign Medicare, saying that new limits on payments would make the program unattractive to many doctors. James H. Stacey, a spokesman for the medical association, said that under the Republican plan doctors in the standard Medicare program were facing not only a cut in the growth of Medicare payments, but also an absolute reduction in payment for many services.

headline.main: A.M.A. Says Plan Would Drive Many Doctors Out of Medicare

docs.lead_paragraph: Just before the audible gasps, before the exhales of "oh, no" and exuberances of "oh, yes" inside the courtroom, there were a few hints that the 12 jurors who decided the fate of O. J. Simpson were sphinxes no more. Sequestered longer than any jury in California history, refusing to betray their thoughts throughout the trial with even the slightest head-shaking or grimacing, they returned this morning and spoke loudly with small gestures.

headline.main: One Juror Smiled; Then They Knew

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation announced yesterday a $750 million charge against third-quarter earnings to increase the reserves it holds to pay insurance claims arising from environmental cleanups and asbestos. The company, based in Philadelphia, said in August that it was contemplating such a step, following the example set earlier this year by Aetna Life and Casualty, and Fireman's Fund, a subsidiary of Allianza A.G., a German insurance company. The two companies set aside a combined total of $1.55 billion.

headline.main: Cigna to Take $750 Million Charge for Cleanup Claims
